responses.content: Our capex is tied to the demand signal. We manage land/data center builds over decades while kit purchases are driven by inferencing and analytic demand. Right now the product mix (consumer/Commercial SaaS/AI meters) is healthy, so we continue to expand with flexibility, but spend only when customers are ready to deploy.

Azure is a port of call for nearly every AI project, with vector databases and Fabric tying into search, Cosmos DB, dev tools, and migrations. Copilot Studio lets enterprises ground copilots in SaaS data; we orchestrate the broader Copilot stack across ServiceNow, SAP, Salesforce and Dynamics.

Generative AI reshapes the entire compute landscape: power, datacenter design, and the app model. Fabric separates storage and compute, letting AI jobs sit atop the same lake house. Every business process is being reimagined through copilots and productivity workflows.

Our computing platform remains aligned with the multi-cloud ecosystem. We keep architectural compatibility while delivering new innovations—HGX, TensorRT LLM, Spectrum-X, H200, Grace Hopper—so every CSP, OEM, and industry vertical can adopt without retooling their stack.

NVIDIA AI Enterprise is the operating system for AI (license-based). We help partners and enterprises build custom models via AI Foundry (AI Foundations + NeMo + DGX Cloud) and support them with software licensing, deployment, and runtime management.

Half of FY24 and Q4 capex went into land/builds financed over 15+ years, providing flexibility across geos. The same infrastructure underpins SaaS and AI usage, and we’re investing globally to align with worldwide demand.
Operating expenses remain tightly managed while funding differentiated AI investments. GAAP margins peaked due to favorable component costs; we expect margins to return to mid-70s as mix normalizes.

Inventory is immediately shipped out; purchase commitments span different time horizons. Our allocation process focuses on customer readiness to deploy, working closely with CSPs to match timing and avoid wasted inventory.

questions: How do you quantify the opportunity that justifies massive capex ramps, and is there truth to the $100B datacenter speculation?
How would you describe the current demand environment for NVIDIA, particularly compared to the cautious tone from other vendors?
When will AI spending become accretive to IT budgets, and how do you see Azure AI projects reallocating spend from core Azure?
Can you unpack the seven-point AI lift to Azure growth, and how do capacity constraints influence that figure?
How are AI partnerships (AWS, Oracle, CoreWeave, etc.) shaping data center capacity and enabling higher Copilot numbers?
What evidence are you seeing that Copilot productivity gains can replicate across broader knowledge worker populations?
Is data quality limiting AI adoption, and are companies making progress in overcoming it?
How much do capacity improvements unblock Azure AI and Microsoft 365 Copilot expansion?
Should we expect Office seat growth and RPU to converge or diverge going forward?
How are you approaching pricing and RPU growth for GitHub Copilot amid strong productivity gains?
How should investors think about gaming growth trajectory after the Activision acquisition?

metadata.note: Summarizes Jensen Huang and Colette Kress remarks plus analyst dialog on AI factories, capex, Copilot, and capacity.
